div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER."

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature's Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.
Depot for Egypt : J. McGregor, Chemist.
Alexandria, Cairo, Ibrahimieh, Luxor, Icilma Co. Ltd., 142, Gray's Inn Road, London, W. C.

div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital JS1.500,000
Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: The N. westerly breeze which has been blowing almost continually for the last month, veered round yesterday to the N.E. The heat and the humidity have increased. This morning opens very sultry. There is a light northerly breeze and a falling harometer. Some wind may be expected towards the close of the day.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: The Engish Daily Newspaper, Established 1886
Editor and Manager - - R. SMELLING
ONE PLASTRE TARIFF
Friday, July 20, 1906.
A DANGEROUS SCHEME.

It is sufficient to say of Mr. Haldane's new Army scheme that it more than realizes the worst rebodings to which expression has been given, says the "Globe." Two battalions of the Gnards and eight battalions of the L'oe are-'o he disbanded. The existing number of 6eld batteries is apparently to be retained, bat their home establishment is to be reduced to a four-gnu basis, except eighteen that are to be put, for some mysterious reason, on a two- gun basis. The net result is a redaction of 3.800 mood in the Riling Artillery, doom pained by an extraordinary arrangement under which certain Militia regiments are to be converted from garrison to Geld artillery, with a view* of supplying the ammnnitim columns to the brigade divisions, and of firm in a Reserve of,gnnnera and drivera. At the time the release of a certain number of ninth of the Regular Garrison Artillery from the dettes of coast defense will allow of their absorption in the Field. The whole of the Militia—Infantry, Artillery, had Beginners -is to be rendered liable to be sent On foreign service, which entails, we • appose, the Goal disappearance of the Militia Ballot, The Volunteers are to be er outraged by the receipt of the abandoned Geld gun*, which Mr. Haldane thinks might be useful in the case of a raid by a Eu rope un Power, and the whole Volunteer force is to be brought into connection with some local authority, -of which the country is to be the unit The details ot this last innovation are still in the dark, and Mr. Haldane Was unable to enlighten the House as to the footings, powers, and constitution of those bodies. Although a total rendition of 20,000 in the Regular AYfny is premised, Mr. Haldane, with the assent outlie) Army Connoil, undertakes to have ready for war an expeditionary force of 160.t)0 \ of wh .m 60,000 msn. will be with the oolongs at home, 70.000 will be Reservists, and the remaining 80,010 mo bilised Militia. The army corps organization is abolished in favor of six big division! of, infantry, containing three brigade! each, after the Indian pattern, four cavalry brigades, and a full complement of artillery, the whole to form a force larger by nearly a third than has hitherto been contemplated for purpose outside the United Kingdom.

0f the disappearance of the term Army Corps we bag no partial complaint to make: it is of German origin; it never Gutted in with oar pa^ system, sod was float to the wind* in time ot war. 'And if a reduction was to be made in the ranks of the Regular Army, it was obvious that the infantry most bus the «offeror* : #vend so, we regret that Mr. Haldane did not are his way to ratio tip cadres of the disappearing battalions rather than resort to the drastic prosoma of disbandment And we think the redaction of the Guards a moat grave error, doe apparently to tome absurd piece of sentiment Bat it' is against interference with the Artillery that we ieel bound to otter the strongest protest of which the language is capable. Mr. Hildaoe gave the film«y pretext that andante pre-sent system only half the existing batteries could be mobilized for want of man and of ammunition columns. Aa Mr. Balfout pointed out in an admirable piece of criticism, a large proportion of these batteries are ot new creation, and time has not yet permitted of the growth of a sufficient Reserve. But this is accumulating year by year, and while nearly 4,000 artillerymen are to be dismissed, Mr. Haldane alters the terms of servi6* for new reaerate, substituting six yean with the toolbars and fix with the Reserve for the present period of three and nine The combination of those two changea most bring about a rapid and automation fall in the number of men annually joining the Reserve The molt its large diminution in the amount of trained artillery experts available for service at home and abroad, in men, moreover, who on neither be improvised or replaced. The makeshift of potting in Militia and Garrison Artillery to assist the Geld batteries is an expedient which we regard with the gravest suspension. Any reference to modem campaign* will show that the ammunition columns require skill and experience discreetly second to what is demanded in the batteries themselves; and the mingling of men trained under diffare'.t conditions and with totally different experiences is bound to introduce a fatal confusion. Mr. Haldane has been guided apparently by the standard of success attained in on# or two picked Militia regiments. WA are afraid he has tens the victim of a generalization based on exceptions. The red notion of the Artillery in South Africa in the face of a native rising, aid the denudation of oar moat important foreign garrisons, IA an act of sheer madness.

Nor does the 'Globe" feel any real oonGdenoe hat Mr.Haldane has secured the 150,000 men for his expeditionary force: his Genres are aim- (vulgarly unconvincing. As we have eo long, been the victim of paper anniee, we may be exoneèd if we hesitate to believe that the present secretary for War has solved the problem that baa be filed all his predecessors. Wa are still met by the old question, when is the British sol tier to come from? The gnat fact remains» that at a moment when the armies outbid- world are striving feverishly to 'ïàoraase their numbers and efficiency, and when the future is black with this prao tical oratory of a straggle for oar national existence, Mr. Haldane proposes to redo the effective strength of the Iritish Army by 20,000 men. The net saving, •o far as we can gather, is to be about a million a year, a windfall which is certain to be appropriated by some crazy fad of modern de moor tie Glance. And was have no guarantee that what is taken eff the shoulders of the not be replaced on those of the ratepayer by the County Associations. These bodies are nebulous for the present, send the utmost we on hype about them is that they will do of harm to the auxiliary forces the probability is that they will be in some shape or other an emanation of tabs County Cannoli. It is '-perfectly 'notorious that many ot those bodies, all the Welsh tance, that of the West Riding of Yorkshire, and the London County Council itself, are opposed root and branch to what they oil militarism. To a substantial section of the Radical party the British uniform is hateful, the British officer a gilded popinjay. To place the destinies of the metropolitan volunteer's node the control of the parochial politicians IA ffying Garden» I* a piece of mere lonely ; but if this IA not contemplated. what does Mr. Haldane mean t of all tabs items in h's disappointing, disheartening, and dangerous programmed, there IA none that will be regarded with moresnspioion than this tampering with the Auxiliary Forces.

div.head: Public Health Dept
div.p: Mr. Goodman,, inspector in the Public Health Department, has left for Upper Egypt, where he will inspect the 'Lffioes of the department.

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: To-day's plague bulletin records a fresh case at Alexandria, the patient-being* young native living at Ли el Tin. Two recoveries are reported from Bibeh.

div.head: The Emir. II. Hag.
div.p: It is said-that Hussein - Pasha Moharrem, A'D.C/'tti H.H.'the Khedive, will probably be appointed Emir El Hag for the 190<> pilgrimage in place of Ibrahim Pasha Fathi.

div.head: Windsor Hotel.
div.p: The cinematograph is certainly a success, and is much appreciated by.* large crowd who can. en jo jb the several, delights of sea breeze, mneio.-and tableaux under -one-canvas.

div.head: Mysterious Murder in Menoufieh.
div.p: The body of a native .was. found -a few days ago in the Bagonrleb Canal, near Birrs Eb Lyan, Menonfieh, with a shot wound in bis body. The murdered man was baried before identification and the murder remain a mystery.

div.head: St. Joseph's-College.
div.p: The annual distribution of prizes at this school will take place on Sunday nexf, 22nd inst., at 4 30 p.m., under the presidency of M. P. Girard, French Consul-General. An excellent musical and dramatic programme has been arranged for the afternoon, and includes a drama entitled-- King Alfred and a ore-act operetta Le Premier Triomphe de Duguesclin, 'which will be taken part in' by the pupils.

div.head: Bead In a-Closed Shop.
div.p: Two days ego a Greek was found, by the police, dead in a dosed i hop in the Darbel Ahmar quarter, Cairo. The post-mortem ex>animation-showed that death had taken place six days- before the door of the shop was opened*; the' police who were dnty in the street were not aware of the fact till the body had reached an advanced stage of decomposition. The body, which canid not be identified, was handed over to the Hellenic consular authorities.

div.head: Attempted Suicide.
div.p: About 6 o'clock yesterday evening, a young European woman was seen to rash towards the quay wall in the eastern harbor, with the evident intention of throwing herself iotd the water. A coastguardsman who happened to .be near by promptly laid hands on her! and prevented her from, carrying her mad project into practice. -Meanwhile -the relative* of the young woman, who is married, appeared on the scene and she was escorted by them back to her booze, from which the had fled in her dressing gown.

div.head: The "Cinemato-Phono."
div.p: We were' privileged last-evening to attend a general rehearsal at the Z-zinia, Theatre of a orientate phono, exhibition. This kind of entertainment, which m a combination of the oine-:marte graph and phonograph worked simultaneously, is by no means new to ns, bat judging| from whit we saw of the repertoire, a very enjoyable entertainment will he provided for the public. la oar opinion-, there is still considerable scope for improvements in the working of the cinema phono, bat the performance aa given at -the- -Z'ziuia is without doubt up to date, and is as effective and perfect as is possible with the, apparatus of the present day. Selections from varions joperas and comio songs were very effectively reproduced. The cinematograph piotnres were - far above the average and were reproduced with sharpness and an entire science of flickering, which was doubt- less a revelation -to many. » Notable among these may be mentioned the marriage of the King of Spain and the coronation of the King and Queen of Norway. Another most acceptable pioture was that of a ship in a stormy sea. This was accompanied by a very realistic imitation of the sound of the waves and plunging of the vessel. The large audience appeared extremely- pleased with the fare provided, and many of the pictures were heartily applauded. We can thoroughly recommend the entertainment as being a most excellent one.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: H.B. Mgr, Photiup, Orthodox-Greek Patriarch of Alexandria, leaves to-day for Cairo.
Mr. Douglas Dnnlop, Adviser to the Ministry of Education, is expected to return from leave on the 17th prox.
We learn with regret of the decease of the Dowager Conntees de Collalto, mother of our popular and esteemed confrère, Count Max di Collalto, Editor of the "Progrès." Our sincere condolences.

M. Pascalingo, judge of the Court of First Instance at Athens, arrives here to-morrow from the Piræns. M Pascalingo will hold an "instruction" in several cases pending, notably the Callioopoulo affair and the Fashn tragedy.
Mohamed Bey Suleiman, private secretary to the Adviser at the Ministry of the Interior, has been granted 70 days' leaue, dating from the 26th inst.
Mr. F. W. Simond, Bâtonnier of the Order of Advocates of Egypt, leaves for Europe this afternoon.

div.head:
GERMAN EAST AFRICA.
DELIMITATION OF NORTHERN FRONTIER.

div.p: The "Kidnische Zeitung" states that the Anglo German Commission, sitting here, has concluded the delimitation of the northern frontier of German East Africa. A complete agreement has been reached. With few alterations, the existing border has been adopted, on account of geological, commercial, and tribunal (1 tribal) conditions. (Reuter)

It is officially announced that the statement appearing in certain French newspapers regarding a German expedition to the Tripoli hinterland organized by Baron Von Oppenheim with' the object of establishing relatione with the Sennsei,. is devoid of foundation. (R.)
A portion of the Natal force is shortly -moving south in order to deal with a Couple of defiant chiefs.' ( Reuter)
The Government gave general support to the Natal Government in yesterday evening's debate. Unionist papers accept with satisfaction the Natal Government's explanations. ( Reuter)

House of Commons.-Sir E. Grey stated that the Government was making enqniriea with regard to- the allegations that the Japan- ese were hampering British trade in Manchuria. The whole question, he said, was receiving attention. (Reuter)

div.head:
RUSSIAN PEASANT AGITATION.
THE HARVEST IN DANGER.

div.p: Peasants burned fifteen properties in the immediate vicinity of the town of Voronesh on Sunday, in broad daylight. Owing to the strike of Polish agrarian laborers the harvest is in danger of being lost. Wholesale murders of policemen are taking place in the province and town Lablin. Ten of them were shot in the latter, place. (Reuter)
Regarding the Agrarian Question, the Duma has passed a. modified amendment expressing the hope that the people will await calmly the result of its labours. The Socialists left the Chamber. (Havas)
King Sisowath has embarked on his return to Cambodia. (Havas)
M. Faîtières has left for Rambouillet (H.)

div.head: DELTA-HOOKER FUSION. AMALGAMATION PROPOSAL REJECTED
div.p: At the meeting held to-day of the Share- holders of the Egyptian Land and General Trust, Limited, the proposal to amalgamate with the Egyptian Delta Land and Investment- Company, Limited, was rejected. The latter company have consequently decided to in- crease the amount of their capital by £400,000 only.

div.head: SURVEYING THE NILE.
div.p: CAPT. LYONS' EXPEDITION.

Captain H. G. Lyons, Director of the Survey Department, who has left England on his return to Cairo, will shortly take ebarge of an important expedition- for the topographical survey of the Nile watershed. It is intended., to obtain levels as far sooth as Laka YiqtoiÂà, and thence another party will work-the-country for the same purpose right down-to-the coast.

A survey of the Nile watershed ha«-never been made, and the present soheme has been undertaken by the Egyptian. Government in connection with the : question оf greater storage of water for the need» of Lower Egypt.
Captain Lyons will have two parties at work in the course of a few weeks, one commencing almost at once from Gondokoro.

div.head: BRITISH GARRISON.
div.p: It is stated that a battalion of the Gnards (according to the "Daily Mail"), the 8rd Coldstream's, with two line battalion* and a field battery have been ordered to hold them- selves in readiness for service in Egypt.

We have been enable this far to obtain any confirmation of the report, which, we imagine, arises from the fact that should any occurrences in Egypt unhappily make a further increase of the garrison necessary) certain units, which are first on the list for foreign service would be eent out.

div.head: ARMY OF OCCUPATION.
div.p: Lient. Col. A. M. Mantell, C.R.E. in Egypt-, and Mrs. Mantell will.embark at;PortSaid on the P. & 0. steamer Mongolia on the 24th inst. for London.
Major J. C. Jameson, R.A.M.C., came down to Alexandria from Cairo to-day on dnty.
A board of officers assembled to-day at Alexandria to examine and report npon the present state of health of Rev. F.B.N. Nor- man-Lee, M.A., Chaplain to the Forces.

' A board of examination will -assemble at Mustapha Ре ' barracks, Alexandria, on Wednesday, 1st August, -and following days for the purpose of superintending the examination of Captain H.F.B. Lewin, R.F.A (E.A.), and Lient. T.H.C. Frankland, 1st Royal Dublin Fusilierp, who are candidates for admission to the Staff College.
Major W. H. Rothôram, R. E., and Miss G. M. Payne, matron, Q.A I.M.N.S., have been granted leave of absence.

div.head: THE LATE COL. SPARKES.
div.p: The death of Colonel W & Sparked C.M.G., retired list, Welsh Regiment, at the early age of forty-four, is very sad, says the "Army and' play Gazette." It was not so long ago that 1 everybody was saying bow lucky he-was rio get ' promotion so early. Yet hie very good luck proved in the end to his disadvantage,1 for he became a colonel in the Army so early in life ( that there was -difficulty in providing for him.

In the province of Bahr el-Ghaaal his - name 1 will long be remembered -m connection -with 1 the work for the reclaiming of that region ' and bringing it back to oivih'sation. He 1 displayed great powers of organization and administration and richly earned the C.M.G. which was -conferred-upon him in acknowledgment of his services. When he * came home and settled down after his retire- 1 ment he seemed to be in robust health. The week before his death be was taken ill whilst c playing polo. Nothing maoh was thought of the matter at the time, bat on looming under medical advice bad symptoms developed, and it was soon ionnd that he was seriously ill. Notwithstanding every care and attention he grew worse, and on the 5th inst. he succumbed 1 to his malady. A correspondent writes of him: - ,£

"I knew poor Sparkes intimately, and knew t well what an earnest, good soldier he was. If I he. had stay(ji on in the Service he could not I have failed to make an even greater mark than he did, for he had all the qualities which go to euanre success ; but there is no don't that his constitution became undermined whilst he j was toiling for the public good. His early death deprives his friends of the companion- ship of one who was popular wherever be went and capable of almost anything in the shape of hard work and responsibility."

div.head: FISHING BOAT DISASTER
div.p: The bodies of the unfortunate Italian fishermen who sank with their boat off the Aboukir I coast on Monday night, as reported in our c columns, have not yet been recovered, and they are supposed to be still in the interior of the vessel. Divers have been at work endeavoring to bring the bodies to the surface, but so far without any success.
The vessel lies at the bottom of the sea and has drifted slightly towards the shore It is hoped that the work of the divers will be more successful to-day.

div.head: CAIRO RAILWAY ACCIDENT.
div.p: PASSENGER SERIOUSLY INJURED.

A railway accident took place yesterday .afternoon ora' Eonbbeh Palace, with the result that three persona were more or less severely . injured and a certain amount of damage done t to rolling stock, etc.

The express which leaves Pont Limonn at ! 1.16 p.m. was entering Koubbeh station when, through some defect in the points where Ы.Н. | the Khedive's special line branches off from the ordinary line, the engine ran - on to the Khédivial line, while aU bot the first of the carriages followed the main line.

The leading carriage was dragged along between the rails,. While the two fractions of the train which it linked, followed their respective line for some 50 yards. At this point the first- carriage, which was being dragged along at right angles to both sets of rails, crashed into the end of the passenger L .platform.. As the engine had shat-off steam, the shook not only stopped it bat sent it back; - -it ran backwards ter a short «distance bod then leaving the rails toppled over on its left side. Had it fallen to the right it .most have in- jured the remaining " carriages, which had also backed down the line towards the points in consequence of the collision of the leading oar with the end of the? platform.

The engine-driver and stoker were both injured by \the fall of the engine and were sent to hospital suffering from severe bruises and general shock. One passenger only was injured, but his injuries are very severe. Besides serious contusions, a compound fracture of the thigh was diagnosed by the doctors called up to give first aid.

It was feared last night that the victim of the accident who is believed to be a son of Yawer Bey—would have to lose the injured limb, the leg having been badly twisted at the moment of or immediately after the fracture.

The break down train composed of five carriages and a crane - arrived shortly before 3 p.m. in charge of Mr. Peaoock and within halfan-hour the line bad been cleared. Unfortunately the results of the accident persisted in a general confusion which lasted till nightfall. Trains were decayed. One is said to have taken half an-hourto get from Pont L;monn to Demerdache and another to have arrived at Pont Limonn nearly an hour late.

Looomotive No. 563, which was injured will require extensive repairs. The damage done to the carriage which collided with the end of the platform at Koubbeh. Palace station is lees considerable than might have been expected. The repairs to the permanent way were completed by 6 p.m.
An enquiry is being bald into the causes of the accident.

div.head: "AL MOAYAD" AND DENISHWAI.
div.p: "Al Moayad" says :—"Some papers assert that the expenses of the Special Court and the pay of the employs who were engaged in the Deniahwai case amounted to LB. 12,000, which amount has been approved by the Ministry of Finance. Bat, as ferae we can judge, there must be a great exaggeration in the amount given. If we take into account all these expenses, according to the circumstances of the case, and include the fares and expenses of the Advisers and the amount paid to counsel for prosecution, the total will scarcely be more than L Б. 2,000. Of the other hand, we can never believe the rumor that the cost of cables to Loudon and the money paid to some of the London papers for producing a sensation have all been put down to the account of the Egyptian Treasury."

With regard to this insinuation made by the editor of "Al Moayad," we should like to remind Sheikh Aly Youssef that England is not Turkey, and that our Press is not subsidised by the Government. If Sheikh Aly Yoursef has any-proof that any British papers or their correspondents have been subsidized by the British authorities here to ipubUsb . sensational versions of the Deniehwai affair, let him give names and proofs. In the meantime we may inform "At Moayad" that the credit opened by the Ministry of Finance does not exceed L.E. 1,200).

div.head: VALI AND SHERIF.
div.p: "Al Mokattam" learns from its correspondent at Suez that differences have arisen between the Vali of the Hedjaz and the Sheriff of Mecca over the hire of oamels travelling between Mecca and Medina. The Vali is said to have advised the latter not to interfere in Arab affairs.

div.head: THE IMPERIAL OTTOMAN BANK
div.p: ANNUAL GENERAL MEETING.

At the annual general meeting of share- holders of this bank, held at Winchester House, Old Broad Street, E.C., the Bari of Beseborougb, C.V.O., C.B., presiding, the Chairman said : Gentlemen, before referring to the report and accounts, you will, I am sure, permit me to express the regret we all feel at the unavoidable absence to day through illness of our esteemed colleague, Lord Hillingdon, and we hope he will soon be with ns again, quite restored to' health. In submitting to you their forty-third annual report and accounts, showing the operations of the bank for the year 1905, the directors have every confidence that they will be regarded as quite satisfactory by the shareholders. From the agricultural point of view the year 1905 has been favorable ; certain lines of railway have seen their receipts augmented, and the total of the kilometrical guarantees paid by the Government was diminished by £57,443, as shown in the following statement :—

The sales of the Régie have grown in notable proportions, and the receipts of the Ottoman Publie Debt have likewise shown an increase, from which the Government is the first to profit. I am pleased to be able to state that our relations with the Imperial Government continue satisfactory. The arrangement for the service of the Maoedonian Treasury commenced in March, 1905—centralizes in the hands of the bank the receipts and expenses of the three Vilayets. We are glad to say that this method works well. Our activity in the provinces has had during the year 1905 a very considerable enlargement, arising not only from the creation of several new agencies and offices, but also from the marked develop * men of the operations of the previously existing agencies, which has given us much encouragement.

We have since the commencement of the present year created new agencies at Kutahia, Xanthi, Tripoli in Barbary, Erzeroum, Caiffa, Aintab, and Kerassund, of which several are already opened. Notwithstanding the initial cost of establishing and administering new agencies, we are of opinion that we ought still to pursue the policy of assisting the Government in developing the resources of the Empire. It has to be borne in mind, however, that the extension of our sphere of action, alluring as the prospect mar be. entails considerable responsibilities and necessitates much pre occupation ; the special requirements of each district and the training and selection of a suitable staff are matters demanding the exercise of judgment and caution, to say nothing of the time which must elapse before a new branch can become remunerative. The deposits of the public continue to show a considerable increase, notwithstanding the active competition of new banke which are allowing higher rates of interest than ours, and we consider that this redounds much to the credit of the bank. I take this opportunity, on behalf of the committee, to thank the managers at the head offices at home and abroad, as well as of the various branches, for their continued close attention to their duties. They have been and are ably sapported by a loyal and trusted staff. In these days of keen com- petition the calls upon the staff of a large institution most be more- frequent than formerly. I am certain that, with our staff constituted as it is, we shall not make those calls in vain, and we shall be always ready to recognize any initiative on their part which in- creases the earning power of the bank. During the present year we have elected as a member of the general committee the Hon. Herbert Lawrence (brother of the Hon. Henry Lawrence, who for many years until his death was & member of the board). Mr. Her- bert Lawrence's election is submitted for confirmation by you to day. I have every confidence th t he will prove of great value to the board. I now, gentlemen, beg to move : "Tlfcat tha report and accounts now read be received and adopted ; that the dividend for the year ending December 31st, 190S, is fixed at 16s. per share, and that this dividend be paid in Constantinople, London and Paris on July 3rd, 1906." (Applause.)
Mone. George Heine seconded the résolution, which was carried unanimously.

The Chairman next proposed that the Baron Hottiuguer and Mone. Pyrame Naville be re elected members of the general committee. Barou Hottingue', he said, was a very distinguished Frenchman. He had been connected with this bank since its commencement, and had been its president in Paris since the year 1902.
Sir W. Lawrence Young seconded the motion, and it was unanimously agreed to.
On the motion of the Chairman, seconded by the Hon. G. J. Gosohen, the Hon. Herbert A. Lawrence was unanimously elected a member of the general committee.

The Chairman : The next resolution is of a special character, and before putting it I have to state that I have been informed by the в irutioeers, who have been properly appointed, that the meeting is constituted in accordance with the statutes for this special purpose. The resolution is -, "That the prolongation of the existence of the company until the year 1925, or such further date as may be decided upon by the committee, be and is hereby authorized." That is the resolution that I beg to move.
This was seconded by Mous. Raoul Mallet, and carried unanimously.

Mr. A. Hood proposed a vote of thanks to the chairman, the general committ:o and the staff. He referred to this wo k which was required to produce nearly half a inillim sterling of profit, which he was sure 'every member of the staff had done his share in producing. He thought, therefore, they ought to remember not only the staff in Constantinople, Paris and Load in, but also those in charge of the various branches. (Hear, hear.)
Mr. A. J. Allen seconded the motion, which was cordially adopted.
The Chairman acknowledged the compliment, and stated that the vote of thanks which had been so unanimously passed would be conveyed to all the members of the staff.
The proceedings then terminated.

div.head: EGYPTIAN GEM SYNDICATE LITIGATION.
div.p: ACTION DISMISSED.

The action by Mr. Edwin William Streeter against the Egyptian Gold and Gem Syndicate, Ltd., was concluded last Wednesday in the Chancery Division before Mr. Justice Neville. Plaintiff claimed a declaration that the company's rights under an agreement had lapsed and that the company had no right oi title to a concession and prospecting 'license.

His Lordship, in giving judgment, said that, according to the agreement (dated 19th March, 1903), the syndicate became entitled to the option of acquiring the plaintiff's concession from the Egyptian Government. Up to the 35th September, 1904, was the period fixed for completion, but before its -expiration plaintiff and the company entered into ten agreement with the Nile Development Syndicate, Ltd., and the time for the completion by the latter was extended till September, 1905, to which extension plaintiff and the defendant company were parties. The Nile Development Syndicate exercised its option, but when it came to the end of the extended time the syndicate was unable to complete its Contract, the result being that the plaintiff and defendant company reverted to their original agreement. It appeareAto the Lordship that according to the agreement of 7th December, 1904, plaintiff joined with the defendant company in the proposal to sell the concession, or. in other words, giving .the option to sell to the Nile Development Syndicate. The agreement of 16th February, 1905, was entered into with a dear recognition of the existence of the principal agreement His Lordship could not make the declaration asked for in the statement of claim, and so far as that was concerned the plaintiff's case failed. In reference to the claim for moneys, he advised counsel on both sides to come to an arrangement as to the amount for which judgment ahold be given, and in view of that he would adjourn that question. SC far as the action to enforce his security was concerned plaintiff would get his costs, but otherwise the action would be dismissed with costs.

div.head: NEW ABBAS THEATRE, CAIRO.
div.p: IL DIAVOLO IN CORPO.

The above piece was given on Wednesday night before a well filled house and proved an excellent evening's entertainment, j edging from the frequent applause metedoutto the artistes. Marenoo's tuneful operetta was well rendered both by singers and orchestra and the staging was, as usual, much above the average for Cairo1. The second act is particularly worthy of mention in this respect, and much credit is due to those responsible for it. Both Signore Baldi and Calligaris performed up to their reputation, the latter delivering two or three notchy songs in very good style. The same may be said of Signori Piraocini and Urbano, who were again the life and soul of the pieoe. They were well seconded by Sig. Saochi, as the Duke, who acted and sang admirably, especially in the scene in the hot with Beita, though his efforts were not folly appreciated by the audience. The chorus was fair and the two dances given in the second act quite delighted the audience, who called for an encore.

We would suggest that the management should make an effort to finish; somewhat earlier, for several people seem to find it too much to remain at the theatre till 12.45, and we quite agree with them. Perhaps this would be remedied by starting a little earlier and curtailing the entr'actes.
La Stiratrice is billed for to night, the ever- popular Geisha tor Saturday, fallowed by the Diavolo in Corpo on Sunday night, with La Stiratrice as a matinée.

div.p: Le Caire, Jeudi 19 J aillât 1906.
L'esoompte libre à Londres, qni est remonté avant-hier à 3 1/8 ponr cent, se maintient k ce tans.

An Stook Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a baissé hier de 1/8 h 87 7/8. L'Unifiée est ren- seignée en hansse de 1/4 à 105 1/4. Malgré le mouvement qni s'est produit ici, la National Bank a clôturé a son prix précédent, soit 25 1/8, de même que l'Agrioole à 9 5/8, la Daïra à 16 3/4 la et la Delta Light à 11 3/4.
A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier Egyptien est restée stationnaire à 751, et la Barque d'Athènes à 151.

Ce matin enoore, notre marché des valeurs a montré de fort bonnes dispositions dès le début de la séance. Mais, par enite de la pénurie d'ordres, le calme n'a pas tardé à prévaloir, aocompagné d'une légère réaotion anr quelques oours. Toutefois l'ensemble de la cote est resté relativement soutenu ; divers titres ont même bénéficié d'une plus-value, notamment dans le compartiment des Hôtels.

La National Bank et l'Agricole ont ooneervé leurs prix d'hier, soit 95 1/2-9/ 6 et 9 11/16- 8/4. La Cassa di Sconto a faibli à 221-222 l'ac- tion ancienne et 214 la nouvelle. La Banque d'Orient est revenue à 132-133. Le Comptoir Financier s'est inscrit à 6 1/4-5/16 l'action ancienne et 6 1/8 la nouvelle.
L'action Crédit Foncier a été offerte à 759- 760. L'obligation à lots 1886 a progressé à 330.
L'aotion Immobiliè-e s'est maintenue à 374 ; par oontre, la part de fondateur a rétrogradé k 660 665.
L'Improvement Corporation s'est raffermie k 4 1/2-9/16, et la part de fondateur Agricole do Nil k 6 7/8.

t L'aotion Allotment est restée k 3 7/16-1/2 ; la part de fondateur est revenue k 123. Les Jouissances Eaux du Caire ont atteint 265 pour finir k 264. La Brasserie des Pyramides a avancé k 124 et les Ciment k 69. La part de fondateur Automobile] a perdu 1/2 livre k 9 1/2.

Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les Nungovioh ont atteint 16 3/16 pour c'ôturer à 16. Eu très benne tendanc®, lee Egyptian (Baehler) ont gagné environ 1/4 de livre k 5 15/16 6. Les Upper Egypt ont progressé k 4 5/8-11/16.
Parmi les petites valeurs, les Estates se sont maintenus k 1 3/4-13/16 ; la part de fondateur a avancé k 10 7 8. Les Oasis ont fait 1 1/8, les Sait & Soda 19 sh. 9 et les Constructions 1 1/4.

Suivant une information télégraphique d'Anvers, l'assemV.ée générale ordinaire de la Compagnie Agricole du Nil, tenue avant hier dans oette ville, a fixé k 5 % le dividende k répartir pour l'exercice 1905-1906, soit Frs. 12,50 par aotion de la 1ère émission.
Nous détachons d'nne lettre de Londres, arrivée par le oonrrier d'hier soir, les lignes snivantes :

"Les nombreux coupons payés depuis le 1er Juillet ont eu snr le marché monétaire nue influence visible, qui a été toutefois atté- nuée par le remboursemeut à la Banque d'An- gleterre des avanoes oonsenties précédemment par oelle ci. Ex réalité, il n'y a guère que les facteurs locanx qui aient sgi sur le loyer de de l'argent ; l'étranger a cessé de nous har- oeler de ses demandes. La Banque parvient à canaliser vers ses oaisses nne quantité appré- ciable de métal jaune, mais cet afflix est partiellement oompensé par les besoins de l'in tériaur. Aussi bien, le taux de l'escompte libre n'a fléohi que d'une minime fraction k 3 1/16 pour oent et il est possible qu'il ne tarde pas à remonter à 3 1/8.

"Depuis quelques jours, on constate, de la part du Stock Exchange, un léger effort pour sortir de l'assoupissement dans lequel il est plongé depuis tant de semaines. A ce reveil contribuent l'attitude des Bourses continen- tales et nne velléité de reprise qui se manifeste sur le marché des mines d'or. L'aotivité est toujours très modérée, les transactions n'ont guère d'ampleur et trahissent une grande prudence ; néanmoins l'ensemble des cours est soulevé par une vague de fermeté calme, mais puissante.''

Ou annonce que l'Egyptian Hotels Co. a veudu, ces jours derniers, deux lots de ses terrains disponibles de Gbezireh pour la somme de 28,090 livres. Il s'agit d'une superfioie totale de 4 099 mètres, qui a été cédée à 7 livres le mètre.

Le conseil des ministres a approuvé, dans sa dernière séance, la formation de trois nou- velles Sociétés anonymes, k savoir: 1" la Sooiété Egyptienne des Pontras et Planchers en oiment ; 2° The Cairo Land and Financial Co. et 3° The Palaoe Hotels of Egypt Co.

Dans son niknéro d'hier, le "Journal Offi- oiel" publie le décret khéiivial. l'acte préli- minaire d'association et les statuts de la pre- mière de ces Sociétés. Son capital est de £2^,000, divisé en 5,000 notions de £4, en- tièrement sousorites par les fondateurs. Le 1er tjoweil d'administration est oomposé de MM. Jompfc Aslan Cattaui Bey, Albert Ismalum Raoul Maggiar et Emile Naeff.

div.head: LES ANGLAIS JUGES PAR EUX-MEMES
div.p: Un de nos confrères du Caire publiait sous ce titre, il a quelques jours, la traduotion d'un article du "Daily Graphio."

Le "Daily Graphio" est ou petit journal il- lustré de Londres, partant, sans grande influ- ence ; il serait oiseux de vouloir lui attribuer l'interprétation d'une population entière Mr. Balfour, k qui l'on oitait.il y a quelques années, le "Daily Graphio" comme journal con- servateur, répondit en p'eine séance de la chambre que cet organe était sans importance politique et que ses allégations avaient fort peu de cré lit auprès de la population.

Noos disons osla simplement pour remettre les choses au point et éviter des malentendus ; il est bien certain que si l'on faisait juger, en Europe, les Egyptiens par eux-mêmes d'après les dires de certains journaux looaux oes juge miats seraient parfois bizarres.

Il y a en Angleterre, comme ioi, des organes importants ayant fait leurs preuves, k l'abri de tout soupçon ; nous ne voyous pas pourquoi l'on va chsroher des arguments dans un jour- nal sans aucune influence dans son pays d'origine, sfin d'établir une soi disant opinion géuérale.

div.head: EGYPTOLOGY AT LIYERROOU! UNIVERSITY.
div.p: While of interest mainly to scholars, and more particularly to students of arobæo- logy, the exhibition of Egyptian antiquities opened last week by Lord Derby in the upper transept of the Derby Museum, Liver- pool, may, the "Liverpool Post" says, be recommended to the attention of the ordinary citizen as a useful object-lesson in remote his- tory, and as a means of giving a healthy stimulus to the imagination. The collection owes its existence to the seventh annual expe- dition to the Nile Valley, under the auspioes of the University Institute of Arobæjlogy, of Mr. John Garstang, reader in Egyptology at the Liverpool University, and Mr. E Harold Jones, whose artistio talents have been of the greatest value towards securing a worthy reoord of this and previous operations ; and both the publio spirited supporters of the Institute and the explorers are entitled to hearty oongratulatiors upon the high intrinsic 1 and historical value of the results or their | latest enterprise. The exhibition, which remains j open till the 26th inst., is at once a tribute to 1 the expert industry of a five months' expedi- 1 tion and a striking evidenoe of the richness | and abundanoe of the spoils of Egypt in these modern days. !

The ohief historical interest centres in the discoveries made in a hitherto undisturbed necropolis near the anoient fortress of Eostam- neh, in the heart of Nubia. Here, about 200 graves were exoavated and searohed, and the objects found are believed to give a clue to the people that formed the earliest population of Egypt, who, many thousands of years B.C., 1 Apparently trekked across the desert from Somaliland to Nubia, where they obviously settled for a long time. As far m oan be judged, i these people retained their primitive civilisa- tion in Nubia long after the rest of Egypt had greatly advanced in development—possibly down to the Twelfth Dynasty (B.C. 2000). It is interesting to note in this connection that a comparison of the results of the researches of Dr. Forbes (Direotor of the Liverpool Museum) in Somaliland and those of the expedition under notice strikingly confirm the theory of the descent of these people from Somaliland, and of the old tradition of the Egyptians them- selves that they were related to the people of that country, with whom they were never at war, but always maintained a firm friendship and an advantageous exobange of products.

The exhibits are, for the most part, arranged chronologically, and the first objeots to claim attention are some highly interesting remains of primitive man found at Eostamneb, dating probably from the First Egyptian Dynasty (B.C. 3000), and suggestive of a erode type of culture. Included are ivory, shell, and bone bracelets, inoised and decorated pottery, im- plements of oopper—axe, knife, chisel, and bradawl ; smooth stone palettes, some hollow- | ed in the oentre by the pounding of pigment, and some retaining the oolonr of green paint ; fragments of primitive matting, and a small oarved ivory comb, sadly damaged by age as regards the teeth, bearing on the obverse the fignre of a man standing before a ' shrine or throne, in the archaic style cf Egypt, * and on the reverse two emblems, possibly an j eagle or an oxhead. A kneading or grinding trough of stonp, hollowed by use, has its in- terest enhanced by comparison wi'h the photo-1 graph of a modern Nubian girl, whose method of bre&dmakiog shows no advanoe on that of five millenniums ago. I

In the same case are shown some mis- ' oellaneons antiquities fonnd by Mr. Jones in ' the palace and temple site of the earliest ' Kings of Egypt at Hierakonpolis, and here is 1 displayed what Mr. Garstang regards as the 1 gem of tie whole collection - an exquisitely- [ worked female head in lapis-lazuli. It is a ' singular thing that the body ot the statuette, whioh is only about four inches high, was | discovered on the same site eight years ago by Quibell, and is the property of the Ash- molean Museum. The head and body are now shown together, and are suggestive of quite a little romance in archeological research.

The exhibition is extraordinarily rich in pottery—pottery of all shapes and sizes and of many colours. The numerous specimens fonnd at Kostamneh are, for the most part, crude as regards 'finish," but they are won- derfully symmetrical, and a few are decorat- ed more or less artistically. ''This complete series," says Mr. Garstang, "provides archaeo- logy with a wealth of new material for ex- tending our knowledge of the inooming and origins of thé historical Egyptians. Many of the types are new and resembled the pieces occasionally found in Egyptian graves of the Twelfth Dynasty (before B.C. 2000). The ma- jority, however, are comparable with the re- cognised types of the First Dyrasty (before B.C. 3000)1"

One of the most attractive oases, especially to the lady visitor, is that oontainiDg the personal ornaments, discovered at Esna (or Esné) and Abydos, both in Upper Egypt, the former celebrated for the temple dedicated to the god Khaum, and the latter a city onoex seoond only to Thebes. These beautiful objects belong chiefly to the Twelfth Dynasty and subsequent periods (B.C, 2000 1'00). Beads and necklaces are numerous, and there is a great variety of materials employed - gold, bronze, ivory, and various stones. The beads I are richly glazed, and a necklace of jasper, and several money- rings of gold, are of special, interest. The little known Hykros period, wh:ch followed the Twelfth Dynasty, is illustrated by a wsit-preserved model of a house, with an outside stairway leading to the flat roof; also ivory carvings, pottery dolls, and some ' examples of faienoe, which include a small dog, ! a blue figure of Bes, and two vases of foreign design suggestive of the possibility of a tariff reform crusade by some forgotten Hyksosian apostle of empire.

To the same period belong several hundreds of soarab seals, the uses of which among the ancients were very extensive, with whom, for instanoe, they answered the same pur- poses as the locks and keys of to day. The rich yield at Esna and Abydos also comprises a series of pottery, some inscribed tombstones, a carved ivory wand, possibly a horoscope, a plaited look of false hair, some ivory hairpins, and a valuable historical inscription embodied in the tombstone of a gentleman who lived in troublous HyksoB times—Enenso, "the Chan- cellor's son," in whose epitaph, it was noticed, the Master of Enowsley showed a paternal concern.

A series of Greek and Coptio stelæ or tomb- stones is of unique interest, ranging in date from B.C. 200 to A.D. 3C0 ; and among the larger objeots on view are the great tomb door of Ehensu, above-mentioned ; a saroopliagos of limestone (from Ema Nineteenth Dynasty) of a chmter in the temple of Amon ; and a mummy case and lid of an Egyptian official who administered the fortress of Eostamneb, about B.C. 1000. M my of these specimens of advanoed art are supposed to belong to the same periods as the cruder workmanship of the Nubian tombs, so that an instructive feature of the exhibition as a whole is the evidenoe it gives of the contemporaneous ex- istence in the Nile Valley.of two civilisations of widely differing stages of development

div.head: A CLAY MOISTENER.
div.p: To many people the best thing about summer is that, like oricket, it provides an excellent excuse for a long drink. Their satisfaction is probably mitigated to a cer- tain extent by the faot that hot weather doss not go well with the consumption of aloohol ; but nowadays there are a great many tem- peranoe drinks which may be apprraohed with good results. A ccntemporary speaks with 1 genuine feeling of a oertain non-alcoholic lager. C'est magnifique, as the Frenoh General said of the charge at Balaolava, mais ce n'est pas , lager. So well is it selling that l£d. a bottle is all that the benevolent vendor demands for ,t. We hear good reports also of ginger ale, which undoubtedly goes down with great ease and pleasantness. Even now, however, we doubt whether the really pet foot summer drink has been invented. Sometimes, in a sort of vision, we get a dim idea of the sort of drink to which we refer, but we have never come across it in real life. It is inexpensive. That is one of its great oharms. It has something of the delicate flavour of barley-water, combined with the robustness of shandygaff. There is a sug- gestion of ohampagne, a suspicion of olaret, a soupçon of orême de menthe, and perhaps a mere shadow of limejuioe. It is good for one. Indeed, ouriously enough, the more one takes, the better one feels. Some day we hope to meet this beverage. At present it is merely, as we say, a vision. ("Globe.")

div.head: AMERICAN COTTON PROSPECTS.
div.p: The view is gaining ground that in the new Beason this summer the American ootton orop will be considerably larger than that of last year. The weather has been very favourable, and tha area under cultivation is deoidedly larger as compared with recent years. It is too soon for an estimate of growth to be issued, but leading trustworthy authorities consider that the outlook at the moment warrants a yield of fully one million bales more than in the cotton year ending August next. Be this as it may, the consumption throughout the world is at full stretch, and new spinning milU are springing up in all directions, notably in Lancashire and the Southern States of America

div.head: MENELIK AND THE TRIPLE ACCORD.
AN ETHIOPIAN DIPLOMAT.
div.p: The Paris Correspondent of the "Pall Mall Gazette" writes:—

What will be the attitude ot the Emperor Menelik towards the new treaty formulated by the representatives of England, France, and . Italy ? I applied to Count Leontieff, a Russian gentleman, who is a personal friend of the t Emperor's, and. for eight years, bis adviser, ] whilst Governor-General of a provinoe. The , Count lives in the quarter of the Etoile, in | a house furnished in the most wonderful | manner with trophieB from Abyssinia, inolud- , ing a sword given bim by Menelik himself. ; He began by saying that if the triple aooord were strictly confined to teohnioal matters, suoh as the construction of railways, Menelik would be perfectly prepared to reoeive it. On the other hand, if it seemed, in any way, by the use of words having a donble meaning, to mortgage the future, then the Emperor would oertainly oppose it most energetically. An agreement arrived at by three neigh- bouring Powers might possibly bear the oom- plexion of a partition of territory after the death of Menelik, but the latter was quite sufficiently a diplomat to rejeot any suoh soheme. He was, indeed, a man of great intelligence aocustomed to reflection and to weighing words.

"When I was advising Menelik," said Count Leontieff, "I suggested that his aim should be to create a neutral country—a sort of African Belgium- -the integrity of which should be guaranteed by all the nations. It was an idea that appealed to him, and he pro- ceeded to act upon it- I may tell you this interesting faot : that when certain difficul- ties began with Franoe, in the firsj instanoe, over the question of the railway,- Menelik consulted the Governments of England, of Russia, and of Italy. His idea was not to seem to favour one at the expense of the others.

"Menelik will, I think, be anxious, in the present oase, to give no cause tor offence to the other Powers interested in the development of Abyssinia. You must remember the im- mense interests of other countries. Foremost among them are the United States of America, which have a large trade in ootton goods, and, in exchange, reoeive ooffae, skins, and ivory. Next in importance oomes the oommerce ot Germany. Austria-Hungary has just established a consulate, and so has Belgium. These Powers will, naturally, not wish to be left out in the oold.

"You ask me the position enjoyed by Eng- land ; it is that of the nation the most respeot- ed and the most listened to. Sir J. Harrington enjoys a high reputation. In a political sense, England is powerful, and enjoys many oon-cessions, but, I believe, that its oommeroe is j surpassed by that of the United States. The t Italians are the most liked of the nations at Addis Abeba, principally beoanse they were t defeated," and M. Leontieff laughed. ' One is ; apt to like the person one does not dread," he i said, "and then the personality of the Italian 1 Consul is much appreciated." 1
"Is it true that Taitou, the wife of Menelik, 1 is under the influence of Turkey, and, there- j fore, of a certain European Power!"

"Oh no. Please dissipate this ancient legend. , Menelik and his wife are much too Christian , to be under the domination of a Mohammedan \ Power. The report has arisen in this way. 1 Taitou, who has oertainly great influence with f her husband, by whom she is consulted on I everything, has the idea of passing her last 1 days at Jerusalem. For that purpose she has I obtained authorisation of the Sultan of Turkey i to build a house in the Holy City. It is a small palace, and happens to be the handsomest within the walls. For this reason, no doubt, it i has been chosen as a residence by the Pasha, 1 who is the Governor of Jerusalem. I do not i know whether the Empress allows him to live f there rent free, but there is, no doubt, aoer- i *a:n give and take in the arrangement. Taitou 4 has also built a new Coptic Chnroh at Jerusa 8 lem. Special authorisation was given by the Saltan. I was sent twioe to Constantinop'e on a ' mission in connection with the religious enter- ' prises of the Empress. On each occassion 1 was 1 well received, and Abdnl Hamid granted wbat was asked of him." s

M. Leontieff expressed confidence in the j future of Abyssinia. "It is the one strong, . purely Afrioan power," he said. "Yon might say that here beats the heart cf Africa. I call * it the country of Future Surprise. The Govern- c ment is strong, in the patriarchal sense. Every- t thing is exaotly regulated by custom and I tradition. Abyssinia is a moral as well as a ] material force ; its morality is the Christian morality, though with the differences that , belong to environment."
"Is it not true that Menelik's policy is to play off one nation against another, and pre- 1 serve Abyssinian integrity that way 1" g
"You must not expeot me to endorse that," j said M. Leontieff, smiling. g
The "Tribuna" (Rome) in what appears to be an officially inspired art:cle, combats some of the views expressed by the "Times" on the Abyssinian agreement. The journal remarks :

"Where the "Times" is entirely mistaken is in supposing that German influence was res- ponsible for the difficulties in the negotiations which have at last been overo-me. With regard to the religions interests which Queen Taitoa protects in Palestine, 6he has always entrusted their protection to Italy, who has alone fulfilled th:s task. As for the rest, it is a faot that Germany, in respeot of the agreement of tbe three Powers, has only concerned herself with the maintenance of the open door, which was guaranteed to her by her oommeroial treaty with the Negus, and for this reason, and no other, was the triple agreement oommunioated I by our Government to Berlin. For no other! reason, sinoe Germany ia not a neighbouring Power, and therefore oannot have territorial aims in Ethiopia, and also because Germany has not felt herself obliged to warn the allied Government of Italy when she on her side has oonoluded other Atrioan conventions with Franoe and England. "

div.head: STAMBOUL AND KOWEÏT.
div.p: Some interesting detai's are given of the Bagdad railway project, which contemplates a distanoe cf abont 1,400 miles from Constanti- nople to the month of the Schat-el-Arab. So far the line reaohes to the foot of the Tanrne Mountains, and the remaining fonr trunk sec- tions to the Persian Gnlf are to be completed by 1919. The line from Tanrus follows the great plateau, which commands the plains of Mesopotamia, orossing the Euphrates, to reaoh Mossnl (Nineveh), where it turns sharply to the Sooth, and reaches Bagdad by the right bank of the Tigris. Recrossing the Euphrates, the route touches Baseorah, and reaches the Gulf, unless diplomatic difficulties forbid, at Koweït. There are to be branch lines to Ourfa, Aleppo, and Beyront. The orossing of the Taurus range, and the opening of the moun- tainous districts dominating the Gulf of Alexandretta, constitute the oruoial difficulties of the enterprise, though, on the other band, the regions travers cl are very rich.

"Thongh I was very ill, I did not suffer aotnal pain, but felt terribly listless and tired, yet nnable to rest. Dizzy fits made me feel as thongh I wonld fall suddenly ; after a short walk I wonld have to stop, feeling shaky, and trembling all over. To go up a few stairs rendered me helpless, for I had to panse every few steps for breath. In a little time I oonld scarcely walk at all, much less look after the hou i e or my six children.

"There was no donbt my state of health was serions. At the Nor- thampton Hospital I had excellent treatment for months, but seemed to get no better. I lost hope, and quite believed I wonld never be well again. It was very distressing to my husband to see me falling into snch a depress- ed, tetribly weak state. But no medical treatment Beemed to rouse me.

"Then I took the advioe of some friends, who insisted that Dr. Williams' Pirk Pills for Pale People wonld effect onres when other medioines had failed. 1 sent to Northampton for a bfix, and am thankful that I did so. div.head: MOUNT TROODOS,
div.p: Cyprus.

A limited number of paying guests can be received by a Lady daring the Summer Months. Cyprus is 34 boars by sea from Port Said. Troodo3 6,406 feet above the sea is a delightful and healthy plaoe amongst the pine forests where the troops and Government Officials spend the hot season.
Terms 2$ Guineas per week.
For further particulars apply to Miss YOUNG,
Nikosia, or to the Editor-
Further Particulars.

Position. The pine covered slopes of Mount Troodos where Miss Young has a camp, are about 6406 feet above the sea ; the troops stationed in Cyprus and the Principal Government Officials live there during the hot season from about June till October. j

Routes. Troodos is about 35 miles from the port of Limassol from which there is a good carriage road to Plâtres 31 m. Beyond Plâtres the road is good but steep and from that point people often ride on mules for the - rest of the journey. There is also an excellent road frdra the Capital, Nicosia, by which persons going from that side of the Island drive all the way (about 16 miles).
Climate. The climate is very dry and healthy; in the daytime it is delightful ; the nights, especially after the end of August, are often rather cold.

Dress. There is a good deal of red dust on the hills, and ladies should be provided with washing skirts. White is a good deal worn, but it is advisable to have some ' brown, fawn, or dust-coloured linen dresses which do not shew dust stains as the washing is not first rate. A warm woollen "coat and skirt" costume is also indispensable.
Rides. There are plenty of delightful rides amongst the hills, but the roads and bridle paths are too steep for bicycles. Mules and ponies can be hired for the season.
Expeditions. Places of interest to be reached on mule or pony back are Kykko Monastery, Kalopanaioti, Trooditissa Monastery, etc.
Games. There is a Tennis Club with two good Courts, there are also one or two private tennis and croquet grounds.
Church. An English Church Service is held twice on Sundays at the Regimental Recreation Room.
Water. The water supply is good and the drinking water pure and wholesome.
Monet. Drafts on the Imperial Ottoman Bank and nglish gold and notes accepted.
By June the railway which runs from Famagusta to Nicosia will be extended to within 20 mile of Nikosia.

Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
